results.title: Dublin
results.brief_description: A practical guide for anyone intending to travel to Ireland’s capital city. Highlights the major cultural attractions and districts. Provides advice on public transport and accommodation. Indicates the best times to visit the main cultural institutions. Suggests places to eat and what you should expect to pay. Includes information on Trinity College, Grafton Street, Waterford Crystal, Powerscourt Gardens, Aran sweaters, literary pub crawls and fishing trips. Presented by John Guerrasio.

results.title: Duane Hanson
results.brief_description: American sculptor Duane Hanson is a major figure in the neo-realist movement. He casts real people in plastic moulds and uses the painted cast, dressed and lifelike figures to make social and political comments which can be disturbing.
results.description: American sculptor Duane Hanson is a major figure in the neo-realist movement. He casts real people in plastic moulds and uses the painted cast, dressed and lifelike figures to make social and political comments which can be disturbing.

results.title: Drylanders
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Peter Jones and Don Haldane
results.brief_description: The epic story of the opening of the Canadian West, and the drought that brought depression in the Thirties. The story begins in 1907 with homesteaders staking life and future on the promise of unproved land. Harassed by winter cold and blazing heat of summer, they learned to farm land where moisture was uncertain. Some found the loneliness and the risk too great and gave up. This family tells of a family who stayed. Cast includes: Frances Hyland, James Douglas and Lester Nixon. Narrated by William Weintraub.

results.title: Dryland salinity
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Cherry Film Productions, Evelyn Cherry and Bill Cherry
results.brief_description: Soil salinity is a problem that seriously affects many farmers in the Great Plains region of the Canadian West. More than two million hectares of cultivated land are already altered by high salt content, and more rich soil is lost each year. As the film explains, agricultural scientists now question certain traditional farm practices, and farmers and researchers are experimenting together to find new grass crops more tolerant of soil salinity. The problem is recognized as a community concern, and solutions do now exist.

results.title: Dry pastures and flood plains
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Frank Bagnall and Jack Rogers
results.brief_description: As well as the difficulties encountered in selling Australia’s surplus of dairy products over our domestic needs, dairy farmers face extremes of climate conditions - lack of adequate regular rainfall, flooding, poor soil, etc. Examines ways of overcoming these difficulties via research into pasture improvement and its application and the introduction of new and improved farming machinery and equipment.

results.title: Dry Hands
results.brief_description: An experimental film capturing the atmosphere of emptiness and boredom which is evident at automatic laundrettes. Contrasts the useless but elegant manicured hands with the constant movement of the washing machine agitating and spinning. Shows the people lounging, smoking, watching the machines and drinking “machine made” coffee to while away the time. They are silent and do nothing, appearing bored, listless and sad in this soulless place which seems to reflect much of life in our modern cities today.

results.title: Drunken boat = Bateau ivre
results.creator_credit: Franfilmdis, Henri Beauvais and Alfred Chaumel
results.brief_description: After the poems of J. Arthur Rimbaud and the symphony “Bateau Ivre” by Robert Bergmann. Prelude for two voices Simon Gantillon and the voice of Rimbaud is Jean-Luis Barrault. In French with no English subtitles.

results.title: Drunken angel
results.creator_credit: Toho Kabushiki Kaisha and Akira Kurosawa
results.brief_description: In 1948 the American army of occupation was still in situ in Japan; Toho, one of Japan’s biggest film production houses and producers of the films of Akira Kurosawa, was riven by strikes - the US Army actually dispersed striking union members who had occupied the Toho site. Against such a backdrop, that any film came out of the Toho state is remarkable. That Kurosawa was able to create a contemporary thriller which was allegorical to the condition of the country, a film rich in traditional Japanese imagery and values, highly esteemed by the critics of his own country - is nothing short of miraculous. Toshiro Mifune takes his first lead role in a Kurosawa film (he became a ‘star’ overnight), playing the sleek but sick young gangster who enlists the help of a shabby, alcoholic doctor, the drunken angel of the title. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Drums of Fu Manchu. Vol. 2
results.creator_credit: Republic Pictures Corporation, William Witney and John English
results.brief_description: Episodes eight to fifteen of this horror/action movie serial. The story line has Fu Manchu (Harry Brandon) in search of the tomb that houses the legendary sceptre of Genghis Khan. His oldest nemesis Sir Nayland Smith (William Royle) stands in his way and creates an adventure that spans from Asia to America. “And with him, comes the thunder of his summons to death -“
